metadata.title: Notable Progress And Developments In The Artificial Intelligence World (Nov 9) | by Richmond Alake | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Notable Progress And Developments In The Artificial Intelligence World (Nov 9)
metadata.description: Keeping up with development and progress that are relevant to machine learning practitioners can be challenging. So, I’ve written an article that provides details of events in the AI field that…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
already enlisted the aid of Palantir

all_paragraphs: Keeping up with development and progress that are relevant to machine learning practitioners can be challenging.
So, I’ve written an article that provides details of events in the AI field that machine learning practitioners will be particularly interested in.

Palantir is a company that has been on the forefront of business news headlines for the past month, and this is mainly due to the once private company filing for an IPO, which has had a successful early debut onto the US stock markets.
For those who are unaware, Palantir is an American company that focuses on creating software and tools for efficient and effective data analysis.
One of the company’s founder is Peter Thiel, co-founder of PayPal and many other successful tech ventures.

Reports have suggested that Palantir and UK government’s officials have been in talks to identify ways Palantir can aid the UK government’s effort in creating a more effective analytics system around its test and trace programme.

Palantir is no stranger to working with countries in handling the Covid-19 pandemic from a data-centric perspective. The data analytics company already works with several countries around the globe and the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
It is probably worth noting that the NHS(National Health Service), the UK’s public healthcare system, as already enlisted the aid of Palantir by leveraging some of its data analytics software.
Click the links below for further information.
MIT researchers have developed a method of Covid-19 detection that leverages AI.
The AI model developed can detect Covid-19 from the audio samples of coughs captured through mobile phones and web browsers.
The researchers report that AI model can pick up minor changes in indicators, which are then used to detect Covid-19 in an individual.

In the research paper, these indicators are referred to as biomarkers. The biomarkers are muscular degradation, vocal cord changes, sentiment changes and changes within the lungs and respiratory system.
The AI model is a combination of neural networks and a designed algorithm that can pick up minute changes in the biomarkers and perform an accurate detection of Covid-19 from cough samples.
The accuracy of the model in detecting Covid-19 from the available cough samples was an impressive 98.5%.

The researchers hope that the AI model can be integrated into a mobile application. The AI model working within a mobile application can boost efforts in the daily surveillance of Covid-19 amongst the population.
More information provided in the following resources:
Intel has recently acquired two machine learning-focused company to boost the chip-making company efforts into the AI sector.
The two latest acquisition by intel includes Cnvrg.io and SigOpt.
Cnvrg.io is a company that has built software and tools to aid data scientist in building and deploying machine learning models.
SigOpt is focused on the optimisation of machine learning models, through automatic model optimisation and development.
It seems the two companies complement each other and no doubt will position Intel as a formidable force in the battle for the global enterprise AI market share.
More information provides in the links below:

A collaboration between IBM and Pfizer research has led to the development of an AI model that can predict the early onset of Alzheimer’s disease in individuals before clinically diagnosis is carried out, or symptoms within individuals develop.

The AI model has a performance score of 70% and works through the analyses of verbal speech samples that are one to two minutes in length. Natural Language Processing techniques are leveraged to analyse the transcribed speech samples.
The speech sample data was provided through the Framingham Heart Study, which encompasses health data points of over 5,000 individuals.
In the future, the AI model can be employed to assist the risk of an individual developing Alzheimer's disease earlier.
More information in the links provided below.
The utilisation of AI to detect several diseases is becoming a reality as the months' pass by.
Soon, we can expect clinicians working with AI embedded software and hardware that can improve the early detection of life-threatening diseases.

Big tech company are not slowing down in their acquisition of promising startups, and there has been an increasing amount of collaboration between research teams to further develop novel techniques to solve real-world problems, particularly around health.
We can only wait and see what developments and progress will be reported next week.
